It could be inevitable now, but I still don't want the US to "go broke": quite apart from the suffering this would inflict on Americans, the crippling shock to the global economy would have incalculable consequences. If the USA should collapse under its pile of debt, millions of people who now like to boast that they hate the American hegemony, would find their prosperity evaporating. 
 
 America is in a political and financial mess; but it is vindictive and, I think, a most short-sighted view that not only desires but delights in the prospect of an American economic catastrophe.

I would say that the Middle East becoming a peaceful and prosperous place is about as likely this century as it is for George W Bush to grow his hair long and move to a New Age hippy commune to find his astral self.
 
 One of the main reasons is exemplified by what is happening in Iraq right now. During the Imperialist phase of European history, right up to the end of WWII it was us who demarcated the borders of countries like Iraq, Jordan, Saudi Arabia, and it was us who put their rulers in place. Iraq is a great example because the three major cultural groups - the Kurds, Sunnis and Shias - identify more with their "tribal" (not sure what the best term is) groups than they do with the concept of "Iraq". Africa has exactly the same problem where huge areas which belonged to one large and powerful tribe were divided up between the British, French, Dutch and Belgians and these divisions eventually became the borders of countries in modern Africa, leading to endless territorial civil war during the late 20th century.
 
 Another thing the ME shares with Africa is astonishingly blatant corruption at every level of authority, Saudi Arabia being the best example with the al-Saud dynasty kept in power by Western arms which also allow them to reap the vast majority of profits from the Saudi oil industry. The presence of such vast quantities of the black gold, and the questions of who has access to it and who profits from it are of course major issues with the potential to cause major problems, no matter what else is achieved in terms of stabilising the region.
 
 There are just too many different ethnic groupings with too many greivances against each other for there to be peace unless something can unify them, and unfortunately the most obvious unifying ideology at the moment is the brand of anti-Western fundamentalist Taliban-style Islam peddled by groups like Al-Qaeda. 
 This same ideology is also vehemently opposed to the presence of Western troops (for ANY reason) in the ME, and equally opposed to the style of leadership currently encountered in most ME countries. The reason that this ideology is proving so popular is that most ordinary ME people agree with these two points, and those who have been most directly affected also jump on the more extreme bandwagon of global Jihad and martyrdom.
 
 I am strongly of the opinion that sometime in the next decade or two we will see a wave of Islamist revolutions across the ME (and central Asia, perhaps north Africa as well) which will bring unimaginable carnage to the region as those in power attempt to maintain the status quo, and those in the West support them to maintain their grip on the ever-more-valuable oil supplies.
 I cannot imagine how such a situation will resolve itself, or how long it will take, but I am 100% certain that it's going to get much, much worse before it starts to get better.
Hansel

 They can share land in peace and they can respect each others beliefs and religious beliefs.

I complement you on your interest in serious matters such as politics and foreign policy. When I was your age my only serious thoughts were of girls and cars. My advise to you is to open your mind to both sides of an argument before you form opinions and be prepared to go where the facts (all of them) and your common sense leads you. If some conservative talk show host makes a statement, know that it is not automatically true. If a liberal (and you should understand the term) says something, it is not automatically false. When you have democrats running things, we do that touchy feely junk, but NOT when the republicans are running things.

Try applying basic math to the approval rating and perhaps you'll understand current administration is disliked by both left and right ideologies. People simply became tired of deceit and lies as a form of government. Even sheeple begin to catch on when a wolf is snacking on their immediate neighbors.

Here's a fact. We are searching for bin Laden. 
lie #1. we have no allocated resources towards searching for bin laden. the most we did was put the word out that he's a wanted man. thats not a search
 
We are fighting the war on terrorism, as our president said.
lie #2. we are invading iraq in order to install a democratic governing system there, and to indefinitely oversee the process. absolutely nothing to do with reducing or eliminating terrorism
 
But in the war we attacked Saddam too. He was a threat. 
lie #3. saddam was not a threat. saddam had no means of being a threat. the most dangerous weapond saddam had in his arsenal were ballistic missles that could travel 800 km.
 
But as of now we are in Afganistan fighting the terrorists, focus on that piece of info. 
lie #4. bin laden and the leaders of al qaeda fled afghanistan over 4 years ago. we are fighting insurgents and rebels in afghanistan, many of who were equiped and trained by al qaeda. but engaging these fighters in gun-fights is doing absolutely nothing to reduce terrorism
 
We are fighting of people who endanger freedom. 
lie #5. we are fighting iraqi insurgents who are not happy about the methods america is using to rearrange their way of life. i take it you dont see the irony in killing people who disagree with the way you want democracy to be for them...
 
I'm sorry if you don't get the picture of freedom, but us as free people have the duty to help those oppresed. 
lie #6. our duty, as every soldier swears to uphold, is to defend american citizen from threats to our freedom. we are invading iraq, who was never a threat to our freedom, and leaving bin laden at large, who is a very real and viable threat. we are not obligated to help countries that are poorer than us. america doesnt have friends, only interests. iraq is an american interest, because of the resources and location, not because we want the iraqi people to be buddies
 
We are helping the Iraqis, what is wrong with that? We are helping the people of Africa. Not in the same way as Iraq but why not critisize that? 

 lie#7. we are positioning ourselves to gain greater control over oil trade and distribution in the middle east. we are not helping the iraqis.
 
 
Patriotism-love for or devotion to one's country 
 I love this country, I would die for this country. 

 if you loved your country youd be interested in hunting bin laden, the person responsible for attacking your country, taking the lives of 3000 civillians, and gripping the country and greater part of the world in grief and fear on september 11th 2001. if you loved your country, youd take the wool out of your eyes and realize that the invasion in iraq cannot possibly reduce or eliminate terrorism in the middle east. if you loved your country youd be appalled by the idea that bush is wasting your country's money and the lives of good men for an operation that does NOT protect the freedom of the citizens, but rather only puts the country in a more vulnerable position while his companies and friends line their pockets with billions in "rebuilding" contracts. if you loved your country youd oppose what the president is doing
 
 do you really love your country?
 
 
The mainstream thesedays falls to the left, and anti-helping anyone. So I don't listen to that. Bush's approval rate is at 29% so the mainstream isn't his view. I have my own view.

 and? help yourself. help your country. the iraqis didnt ask for our help. our media magnified the acts of saddam to make him look like the biggest fiend on the planet, while in out beloved saudi, egypt, syria, jordan and oman, the politics are just as bad, the oppression is just as severe and the terrorists are even more at home than even in iraq. if anybody needs a reform its those countries: the countries that have REAL ties to bin laden. you cover your ears to that because its contrary to what the president says. but its the truth, like it or not

 Well said. I personally find it difficult to comprehend the thought processes that motivate some of our US citizenry to follow and believe in a constant stream of deception, lies and refocus. If those who believe current administration is putting our country first, as they should, would open their closed minds and use rational thinking rather than contrived emotion wrapped and presented in a flag to evaluate our actions, perhaps they wouldn't sound so naive. Or as the case might be, dumb. If I hear one more rationalization that the world is a better place without Saddam and well worth the price we're paying, I'll know we're doomed to intellectual mediocrity or an even lower standard of mental well-being.

 I know this idea is far fetched, but I've heard of some debates getting started of him hiding out in America...The one place where no one would expect to find him. Don't most people expect him to be in Afghanistan? Doesn't he have the ability to travel in and out of countries? I thought I heard back in about 2002 that he was seen near the Afghanistan/Pakistan boarder. Could he easily slip to another country over night and wind up in another country during the night and wind up in any other country? Infact, for all we know, he could be dead; not from troops fire but from natural causes. He does have a liver problem or internal organ like that. My main point is that we don't honestly know where he is right now.

 nobody from aghanistan was on any of the planes that flew the :xcensored planes into the world trade towers. the terrorists were egyptian, saudi and yemeni. we havent sent a single investigative unit to check out leads in any of these countries. but we are in afghanistan, flying in 2 months after we knew that bin laden was behind the attacks.
 
 bush has done everything he possibly could to make sure that bin laden was NOT captured. he authorised the flights of the bin laden family members out of the country 2 days after the attack. he gave bin laden and the taliban leaders 2 months to pack up and leave before we went into afghanistan. and now he is letting bin laden wreak havoc as he pleases with no american forces on his his tail. right now, bin laden gets better treatment from bush than many americans do
 
 even if bin laden is hiding in afghanistan, searching for him is not why we have soldiers there. the reason we have troops in afghanistan is to prevent the artificially installed leadership from being violently ousted by the afghanistan people. we put kazaad (sp) as leader of afghanistan, and we gun down anybody who opposes or threatens his position there. its a quick-fix form of democracy, without the democratic part. the other reason why we have troops in afghanistan is because we have been awarded a contract by the afghanistani leader (heh heh) to construct an oil pipeline through the country to the caspian sea. so our troops in afghanistan have their work cut out for them. they dont even have time to search for bin laden, even if he was hiding there

This is just as good as if American soldiers lines up and shot each other.

 I would say that you are both right, and both wrong. Yes, it is an econimic war...all wars are economic in nature. BL is getting what he wanted. And yes, our war on terror has fueled the insurgency. But the notion that the US would be better off like the Pre 9/11 era (fat, dumb, and happy) is just a rediculous notion. Isolationism and appeasment are temporary fixes at best. Didn't work pre 9/11, probably not the best policy post 9/11. My general opinion is that the answer lies somewhere in between. Finding that happy medium is the real problem.

 Peace is definatly on the way. Poll results show that regardless of who wins, there will be close treaties with Iran, since the US backed canidates do not have a snowballs chance in hell. With Iran and Iraq closely alinged, US participation and control in the ME are a thing of the past. 
 
 The Sunnis have bene actively campaigning to elect leaders to support and protect IRan becuase they know as well as anybody that IRans Euro based oil market, set to open next year, is the end of the petro dollar. Every OPEC nation has already agrees to sell there, and in Euros, and every major oil importer has reserved a slot to buy. 
 
 Iran and Syria already have a mutual defense pact, and Iraq has already been brougth intot hat fold. The russians are backing it by providing Syria and Iran both modern anti aircraft systems to protect against potential attacks. Israel cannot possibly stand against a united Syria, Iran, and Iraq, even with US support. Their only option would be Nukes, which would almost certainly turn the entire world against them. In short, the odds of israel existing past 10 years is pretty slim with an Iran/Iraq/Syrian conglomerate in the ME.
 
 So in short, YES, there will probably be peace in the ME. How that peace will be arrived at is absolutly the worst case scenario for the US or the western world, but there WILL be peace.
